awd_titl_txt: Enhancing and Sustaining the CISE REU Site Evaluation Toolkit
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides long-term support for external evaluation activities and services for the Computing and Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) community. This project addresses the ongoing need among principal investigators who are conducting CISE REU Site program evaluation efforts by providing an evaluation toolkit that facilitates evaluation reporting while strengthening research about undergraduate research program outcomes. The primary purpose of the CISE REU Evaluation Toolkit is to provide targeted resources and tools for quality program evaluation that balance the desire for standardized assessment along with the responsibility to account for individual program contexts. This project aims to enhance the evaluation tools and resources and to provide for sustainability and maintenance of the resources.  Services associated with the Toolkit are providing a Common Application for site recruiting, coordinating a Shared Applicant Pool for principal investigators to share applicants across sites, delivering an online student survey known as the A la Carte Student Survey,and providing an Alumni Tracker tool to assist sites with tracking their students after their participation in summer research at the site.  The project also provides aggregate and site-specific analyses to REU Site principal investigators. The benefits of the Toolkit are in providing cost effective, sustainable evaluation tools, a community forum for program evaluation, and aggregate measurement of key program outcomes indicators. 

The key contribution of project is in the refinement of understanding evidence-based practices in evaluating undergraduate research programs to help faculty successfully manage these programs. The goals of the project include managing the various components of the Toolkit, providing analyses and summative annual reporting of the Evaluation Toolkit results, and providing timely, site-specific data packages of student results.  The strength of this project comes from the strong research community of practice that has been nurtured by this project and the ongoing commitment to support and enhance the resources through this funding. The project contributes to understanding the impact of undergraduate computing research programs for both students and faculty participants. The comprehensive program evaluation will inform collective efforts to recruit and mentor undergraduate students involved in cutting-edge research. The knowledge generated by this study will also provide insights about how faculty engage in REU Sites and the impact on their careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CISE REU Evaluation Toolkit project was born out of an expressed need among  faculty who manage summer research experiences for undergraduates (REUs) within the Computing Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE) fields. Launched in 2010 and managed with NSF support for 10 years, the Toolkit project provided evaluation and outcomes assessment support to faculty overseeing summer REUS, and also provided aggregate summative information about undergraduate students who apply to and participate in summer research. The tools contained in the Toolkit included the following.

Common Application: This was a standardized set of application questions that faculty used to manage student applications to their research programs. The applicant data was aggregated annually and shared across the CISE REU Programs to inform the community about trends in student interest in research and the demographics of the applicant pool.

Shared Applicant Pool: This feature of the Toolkit provided students who apply to a summer research program with greater opportunities to be considered by other summer programs, if they wished. It also allowed faculty to expand their pool of candidates for their summer programs.

A la Carte Student Survey: The pre and post student survey was designed to measure student outcomes from their program participation that were aligned with the CISE REU program goals. It?s known as ?a la carte? because it is designed to be modular, and faculty can tailor it to their specific programs. For example, all faculty used the student ?self-efficacy module,? some included the ?sense of belonging module.? This survey is a validated instrument for measuring student attitudes about computing research and their likelihood of persisting, and is publicly available on the Toolkit website.

Alumni Tracker: This feature provided a set of common follow up questions so that students who participated in an REU could report graduations, entrance into graduate school, and career successes.

Online Resources: The Toolkit features are provided as open-source on its website, which remain available after the project funding cycle. Resources are curated to address the unique context of undergraduate research programs in computing. Many other disciplines have used the resources, such as Engineering and Chemistry research programs.

 

Highlights of Student Outcomes 2010-2022

The Toolkit supported faculty who manage undergraduate research programs, and remains as an information hub about program evaluation for undergraduate research programs.

  • Student applications to the CISE REU programs increased 5-fold over ten years.
  • Students gains in research skills were observed every year.
  • Students' belief in their computing abilities have increased statistically for 9 years in a row.

These findings are indicative that the CISE REU Program is making a positive impact on students in computing. The Toolkit resources made this information possible to capture and share with the community, by providing mechanisms to show consistent outcomes across all projects. The Toolkit resources have provided faculty who manage REU projects access to evaluation and measurement resources that are relevant, customizable, and save them time and effort.
